editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Acted at the Globe by his Maiesties Servants.
Written by Francis Baymont and Iohn Fletcher. Gent.
Printed at London for Thomas Walkley, and are to be sold at his shop at the Eagle and Child in Brittaines Bursse. 1620.

div.head: Actus 1. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter at seuerall doores Lord LYON, TRASILINE followes him, CLERIMON meetes them.

sp.speaker: TRASILINE.
sp.p: WEll over taken my Lord.

sp.speaker: LYON.
sp.p: Noble friend welcome, and see who encounters us, honourable good Clerimon.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: My good Lord Lyon, most happily met worthy Traefilme,
Come gallants, whats the news,
the season affords us variety,
the novelists of our time runs on heaps,
to glut their itching ears with airy sounds,
trotting to the burse; and in the Temple walk
with greater zeal to hear a novel lie,
than a pious Anthem though chanted by Cherubims.

sp.speaker: TRANS.
sp.l: True Sir:
and holds set counsels, to vent their brain sick opinions
with presagements what all states shall design.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: That is as their intelligence serves.

sp.speaker: LYON
sp.l: And that shall serve as long as invention lasts,
their dreams they relate, as spoke from Oracles,
or if the gods should hold a synod, and make them their secretaries,
they will divine and prophecy too: but come and speak your
thoughts of the intended marriage with the Spanish Prince,
He is come you see, and bravely entertained.

sp.speaker: TRAS.
sp.p: He is so, but not married yet.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: But like to be, and shall have in dowry with the Princess this Kingdom of Cycele.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Soft and fair, there is more will forbid the bans, than say amen to the marriage: though the King usurped the Kingdom, during the non-age of the Prince Phylaster, he must not think to bereave him of it quite; he is now come to years to claim the Crown.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: And lose his head in the asking.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: A diadem worn by a headless King wold be wondrous, Phylaster is too weak in power.

sp.speaker: GLE.
sp.p: He hath many friends.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: And few helpers.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: The people love him.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: I grant it, that the King knows too well,
And makes this Contract to make his faction strong:
Whats a giddy-headed multitude,
That is not Disciplined nor trained up in Arms,
To be trusted unto? No, he that will
Bandy for a Monarchy, must provide
Brave marshall troops with resolution armed,
To stand the shock of bloody doubtful war,
Not daunted though disastrous Fate doth frown,
And spit all spiteful fury in their face:
Defying horror in her ugliest form,
And grows more valiant, the more danger threats;
Or let lean famine her affliction send,
Whose pining plagues a second hell doth bring,
They will hold their courage in her height of spleen,
Till valour win plenty to supply them,
What think ye, would yer feast-hunting Citizens
Endure this?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: No sir, a fair march a mile out of town that their wives may bring them their dinners, is the hottest service that they are trained up to.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: I could wish their experience answered their loves,
Then should the much too much wronged Phylaster,
Possess his right in spite of Don and the devil.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: My heart is with your wishes.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: And so is mine,
And so should all that loves their true born Prince,
Then let us join our Forces with our minds,
In whats our power to right this wronged Lord,
And watch advantage as best may fit the time
To stir the murmuring people up,
Who is already possessed with his wrongs,
And easily would in rebellion rise,
Which full well the King doth both know and fear,
But first our service we will proffer to the Prince,
And set our projects as he accepts of us;
But hushed, the King is coming.

div.stage: Enter the King, PHARAMONT, the Princesse, the Lady GALLATEA, the Lady MEGRA, a Gentlewoman, with Lords attending, the King takes his seate.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Fair Prince,
Since heavens great guider furthers our intents,
And brought you with safety here to arrive
Within our Kingdom and Court of Cycele,
We bid you most welcome, Princely Pharamont,
And that our Kingly bounty shall confirm,
Even whilst the Heavens hold so propitious aspect
We will crown your wished desires (with our own)
Lend me your hand sweet Prince, hereby enjoy
A full fruition of your best contents,
The interest I hold I do possess you with,
Only a fathers care and prayers retain,
That heaven may heap on blessings, take her Prince,
A sweeter Mistress than the offered Language of any dame,
were she a Queen whose eye speaks common Loves;
sp.p: and comfort to her servants: Last Noble son, for so I now must call you, what I have done thus public, is not to add a comfort in particular to you or me, but all, and to confirm the Nobles and the Gentry of our Kingdom by oath to your succession: which shall be within this month at most.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: This will be hardly done.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: It must be ill done, if it be done.

sp.speaker: LEON
sp.l: When it is at best, it will be but half done,
whilst so brave a gentleman is wronged and slung off.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: I fear.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Who does not?

sp.speaker: LEON
sp.l: I fear not for myself, and yet I fear too:
well, we shall see, we shall see: no more.

sp.speaker: PHARAMONT
sp.p: Kissing your white hand Mistress I take leave, to thank your royal Father: and thus far to be my own free trumpet: understand great King, and these your subjects, mine that must be, for so deserving you have spoke me Sir: and so deserving I dare speak myself, to what a person of what Eminence, ripe expectation, of what faculties, manners and vertues you would wed your Kingdoms, and in me have your wishes: o this country, by more than all the gods, I hold it happy, happy in their dear memories, that have been Kings great and good; happy in yours that is, and from you as a Chronicle to keep your noble name from rotting Age: do I open myself most happy: Gentlemen believe me in a word, a Princes word, there shall be nothing to make up a Kingdom mighty and flourishing, defenced feared equal to be commanded and obeyed but through the travels of my life, I will find it out, and tie it to this country. By all the gods; my Reign shall be as easy to the subjects, that every man shall be his Prince himself, and his own Law; Yet I his Prince and Law. And dearest Lady, to your dearest self, dear in the choice of him, whose name and lustre, must make you more and mightier: Let me say you are the blessedest living: for sweet Princess, you shall enjoy a man of men, to be your servant, you shall make him yours, for whom great Queens must die.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Miracles!

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: This speech calls him Spaniard, being nothing
but a large Inventory of his own commendations.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: I wonder whats his price?
for certainly he will sell him, he has so be praised his shape:
sp.p: But here comes one, more worthy those large praises, than the large speaker of them; Let me be swallowed quick, if I can find all the Anatomy of yon man's vertues unseen to sound enough, to promise for him, he shall be Constable by this Sun: he will never make King, unless it be of trifles in my poor judgment.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Right noble sir, as low as my obedience,
with a heart as loyal as my knee, I beg for favour.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Rise, you have it sir.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Mark but the King how pale he looks, he fears,
and this same whoreson conscience, ah how it jades us.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Speak your intents sir.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: Shall I speak on freely, be still my royal Sovereign.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: As a subject we give you freedom.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Now it heats.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: Then thus I turn my language to you Prince, you foreign man never start, nor put on wonder; you must endure me, and you shall: This earth you tread upon, a dowry as you hope with this sweet Princess, whose memory I bow to, was not left by my dead father, O I had a father: to your inheritance, and I up and living, having myself about me and my sword the souls of all my name and memories: these arms and some few friends besides the gods to part so calmly with it, and sit still and say I might have been, I tell thee Pharamont, when thou art King, look I be dead and rotten, and my name ashes, as I: for hear me Pharamont, this very ground thou goest on, this fat earth my fathers friends made fertile with their faiths: before that day of shame shall gape and swallow thee and thy nation, like a hungry grave into his hidden bowels: Prince it shall, by the just gods it shall.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: He is mad, beyond cure mad.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Here is a fellow has some fire in his veins,
the outlandish Prince looks like a tooth-drawer.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Aye Prince of popinjays, I will make it well appear
to you I am not mad.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: You displease us, you are too bold.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: No sir, I am too tame, too much a Turtle,
A thing born without passion, a faint shadow:
That every drunken cloud sails over,
And make nothing.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I do not fancy this choler,
Sure he is somewhat tainted.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: I do not think it will prove so.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Has given him a general purge already, for all the right he
has, and now he means to let him blood: be constant
gentle heavens, I will run his hazard although
I run my name out of the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Peace, we are all one soul.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: What you have seen in me to stir offence,
I cannot find, unless it be this Lady offered into my arms,
with the succession which I must keep: though is hath
pleased your fury to mutiny within you, without disputing,
your Genealogies or taking knowledge whose branch you are,
the King will leave it to me,
and I dare make it mine: you have your answer.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: If thou wert sole inheritor to him
That made the world his,
And couldst see no Sun shine upon anything but thine,
Were Pharamont as truly valiant as I feele him cold,
And ringed amongst the choicest of his friends: such
As would blush to talk such serious follies,
Or back such belied commendations: and from his presence
Spit all those brags, you should hear further from me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sir, you wrong the Prince, I gave you not this freedom,
go to, be better tempered.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: It must be sir, when I am nobler used.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Ladies, this would have been a pattern of succession,
Had he never met this mischief: by my life this is
The worthiest: the true name of man this day within
My knowledge.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: I cannot tell what you may call knowledge,
but I am sure the others the man set in my eye,
O it is a Prince of wax.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: A dog it is.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Phylaster, tell me the injuries you aim at in your riddles.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: If you had my eyes sir and sufferance,
My grief upon you, and my broken fortunes,
My wants great, and now nothing hopes and fears,
My wrongs would make ill riddles to be laughed at:
Dare you be still my King, and right me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Give me your wrongs in private.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: He dares not stand the shock.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: I cannot blame him, there is danger in it.
sp.p: Every man in this Age has a soul of Crystal, to read their actions, though men's faces are so far asunder, that they hold no intelligence: but view the stranger well, and you shall see a fever throw all his braveries, and feele him shack like a true truant, if he give not back his Crown again, upon the report of an elder gun: I am no augery.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Go to, be more yourself, as you respect our favour, You will stir us else: sir I must have you know, that you are, and shall be at our pleasure, what fashion we will put upon you, smooth yourself, over or by the gods

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I am dead sir, you are my Fate, it was not I said I was wronged, I carry all about me, my weak stars lead me too: all my weak fortunes, who dare in all this presence speak, that is but man of flesh, and may be mortal, tell me, I do not most entirely love this Prince, and honour his full vertues.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: He is possessed.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Yes, with my fathers spirit is here O king,
a dangerous spirit, and now he tells me king,
I was a kings Heir, bids me be a king, and whispers
to me, these are all my subjects, it is strange he will
not let me sleep: but dives into my fancy, and there
gives me shapes that kneel and do me service,
cry me king, but I will suppress him, he is a factious
spirit and will undo me: Noble sir your hand,
I am your servant.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Away I do not like this,
sp.p: I will make you tamer, or I will dispossess you both of your life and spirit: for this time I pardon your willed speech, without so much as imprisonment.

sp.speaker: LYON
sp.p: I thank you sir, you dare not for the people.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Ladies what think you now of this brave fellow.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: A pretty talking fellow hot at hand: but eye yon stranger, is he not a fine complete Gentleman? O these strangers, I do affect them strangely, they do the rarest home things, and please the fullest, as I live I could love all their Nation over and over for his sake.

sp.speaker: LAD.
sp.p: Gods comfort, your poor head-piece it is a weak one, and has need of an night-cap.

sp.speaker: LYON
sp.p: See how his fancy labours, has he not spoke home and bravely, what a dangerous train did he give fire to, how he shook the King, made his soul melt within him, and his blood run into whey: it stood upon his brow like a cold winter dew.

sp.speaker: PHY.
CEE.
sp.p: How do your worth sir.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Well, very well, and so well, that if the King please,
I may live many years.

sp.speaker: LYON
sp.l: Sir, the King must please:
sp.p: Whilst we know who you are, and what you are, your wrongs and vertues shrink not worthy sir: but call your father to you, in whose name we will waken all the gods, and conjure up the rods of vengeance, the abused people, who like raging torrents shall swell hie: and so begirt the dens of these Male-dragons, that through the strongest safety they shall beg for mercy at your swords point.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: Friend no more, our ears may be corrupted, it is an Age we dare not trust our wills to, do you love me?

sp.speaker: TRAS.
sp.p: Do we love heaven and honour?

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: My Lord Lyon you had a virtuous Gentlewoman
called you father, is she yet alive.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Most honoured sir she is, and for a penance but of an idle dream, has undertook a tedious pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Is it to me, or to any of these Gentlemen you come.

sp.speaker: GENT. WOO.
sp.p: To you, brave Lord, the Princess would entreat your present company.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: The Princess send for me, you are mistaken,

sp.speaker: GENT. WOO.
sp.p: If you be called Phylaster, it is you.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Kiss her fair hand, and say I will attend her.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Do you know what you do?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Yes, go to see a woman.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: But do you weigh the danger you are in?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Danger in a sweet face: By Jupiter I must not fear a woman.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.l: But are you sure it was the Princess sent,
It may be some foul train to catch your life.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I dare not think it Gentlemen, she is noble, her eye may shoot me dead, or those true red and white fiend friends in her cheeks, may steal my soul out, there is all the danger in it: but be what may, her single name hath armed me.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Go on, and be as truly happy as thou art fearless:
Come Gentlemen, let us make our friends acquainted, lest the king prove false.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Comes he not.

sp.speaker: WOO.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Will Phylaster come?

sp.speaker: WOO.
sp.p: Dear Madam, you were wont to credit me at the first.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: But didst thou tell me so.

I am forgetful, and my woman's strength is so over charged, with dangers like to grow about my marriage, that these under things dares not abide in such a troubled sea, how looked he when he told thee he would come?

sp.speaker: WOO.
sp.p: Why well.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: And not a little fearful.

sp.speaker: WOO.
sp.p: Fear Madam, sure he knows not what it is,

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: You all are of his faction, the whole Court is bold in praise of him, whilst I may live neglected, and do noble things, as fools in strife throw gold into the sea, drowned in the doing: but I know he fears.

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Madam, methought his looks hid more of love than fear.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Of love, to whom: to you, did you deliver those plain words I sent, with such a wooing gesture and quick looks that you have caught.

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Madam I mean to you.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Of love to me: alas, thy ignorance lets thee not see the crosses of our births, nature that loves not to be questioned: why she did this, or that, but has his ends, and knows she does well: never gave the world to things so opposite, so bound to put as he and I am, if a bowl of blood drawn from this arm, would poison thee, a draught of his would cure thee: love to me.

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Madam, I think I hear him.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Bring him in: you gods that will not have your dens with. stood, whose holy wisdoms at this time it is to make the passions of a feeble maid, the way into your Justice, I obey.

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Here is my Lord Phylaster.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: O it is well, withdraw yourself.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Madam, your messenger.
made me believe you wished to speak with me.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: It is true Phylaster, but the words are such I have to say,
and does so ill become the mouth of woman,
that I wish them said, and yet am loath to speak them.
Have you known that I have aught detracted
from your worth: have I in person wronged you?
or have set my baser Instruments to throw disgrace
upon your vertues.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Never madam you.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Why then should you in such a public place,
Injure a Princess, and a scandal lay upon my fortunes,
found to be so great: calling a great part of my dowry in question.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Madam, this truth which I shall speak, will be foolish: but for your fair virtuous self, I could afford myself to have no right to anything you wished.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Phylaster, know I must enjoy these Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Madam both?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Both, or I do, by heaven I die Phylaster,
if I not calmly die enjoy them both,

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I would do much to save that noble life,
yet would be loath to have posterity find in our stories,
that Phylaster gave his right unto a Sceptre and a Crown,
to save a Ladies longing.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Nay then hear, I must and will have them, and more.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Or lose that little life the gods prepared,
to trouble this poor piece of earth with all.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Madam, what more?

sp.speaker: PRIH.
sp.p: Turn then away thy face.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I can endure it: turn away my face,
I never saw yet enemy that looked so dreadfully,
But that I thought myself as great a basilisk as he,
Or speak so horrible, but that I thought my tongue
Bore thunder underneath as much as his:
Nor beast that I could turn from, shall I then begin,
To fear sweet sounds, a woman's tongue, whom I do love,
Say you would have my life, why I will give it you,
For it is of me a thing so loathed, and unto you that beg,
Of so poor use, that I shall make no price,
If you entreat, I will unmovedly hear.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Yet for my sake a little bend thy looks.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Then know I must have them and thee.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And me!

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Thy love, without which, all the land discovered yet, will serve me for no use, but to be buried in.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Is it possible.

sp.speaker: PRI.
sp.p: With it, it were too little to bestow on thee, now though thy breath strike me dead, which know it may, I have unripped my breast.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Madam, you are too full of noble thoughts,
to lay a train for this contemned life,
sp.p: which you might have for asking, to suspect were base, where I deserve no ill: love you by all my hopes, I do above my life, but how this passion should proceed from you so violently, would amaze a man that would be Jealous.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Another soul into my body shot,
Could not have filled me with more strength and spirit,
Than this thy breath, but spend not hasty time
In seeking how I came thus: it is the gods that make me so,
And sure our love will be the worthier, and the better
Blessed, in that the secret justice of the gods
Is mingled with it: let us leave, and kiss, lest some
Unlessoned guest should fall betwixt us,
And we should part without it.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: It will be ill I should abide here long.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: It is true, and worse you should come often.
How shall we devise to hold intelligence?
That our true loves, on an new occasion may agree,
What path is best to tread.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: I have a boy, sent by the gods, I hope to this intent, not yet seen in the Court, hunting the buck I found him sitting by a fountain side, of which he borrowed some, to quench his thirst, and paid the nymph as much again in tears: a Garland lay him by, made by himself, of many several flowers, bred in the veil, stuck in that mystic order that the rareness delighted me, but ever when he turned his tender eye upon um, he would weep as if he meant to make them grow again, seeing such pretty helpless innocence dwell in his face: I asked him all his story, he told me that his parents gentle died, leaving him to the mercy of the fields: which gave him roots, and of the crystal springs, which did not stop the course, and the Sun, which still he thanked, it yielded him his life: then took he up his garland, and did show what every flower, as country people hold, did signify, and how all ordered thus expressed his grief, and to my thoughts did read the prettiest lecture of his country art, that could be wished, so that methought I could have studied it, I gladly entertained him, whom was glad to follow: and have got the trustiest, lovingest, and the gentlest boy that ever master kept, him will I send to wait on you and bear our hidden love.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: It is well, no more.

sp.speaker: WOO.
sp.p: Madam, the Prince is come to do his service.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: What will you Phylaster do with yourself?

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: Why? that which all the gods have appointed out for me.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Dear, hide thyself, bring in the Prince.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Hide me from Pharamont:
When thunder speaks, which is the voice of God,
Though I do reverence, yet I do not hide myself,
And shall a stranger Prince have leave to brag
Unto a foreign Nation, that he made Phylaster
hide himself.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: He cannot know it.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Though it should sleep for ever to the world,
it is a simple sin to hide myself, which will for ever
on my conscience lie.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Then good Phylaster give him scope and way
in what he says: for he is apt to speak
what you are loath to hear.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: PHAR.
sp.l: My Princely Mistress, as true lovers ought,
I come to kiss these fair hands, and to show in outward ceremonies,
the dear love within my heart.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: If I shall have an answer or no, directly I am gone.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: To what? what would he have answer?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: To his claim unto the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Sirrah, I forbear you before the King.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Good sir do so still, I would not talk with you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: But now the time is fitter, do but offer to make mention of right to any kingdom, though it lie scarce habitable.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Good sir let me go.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: And by the gods

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Peace Pharamont, if then

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I have done.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: You shall not need.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Know Pharamont I loath to brawl with such a blast as thou, who are nothing but a valiant voice, but if thou shalt provoke me further, men shall say thou wert, and not lament it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Do you sleight my greatness so much,
and in the chamber of the Princess?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: It is a place to which I must confess, I owe a reverence, but wert the Church at the high Altar, there is no place so safe, where thou darest injury me, but I dare kill thee: and for your greatness, know I can grasp you and your greatness, thus, thus, into nothing: give not a word, not a word back, farewell.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: It is an odd fellow Madam, we must stop his mouth with some office when we are married.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: You were best make him your Controller.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I think he would discharge it well.

Madam, I hope our hearts are knit, but yet so slow, the ceremonies of state are, that it will be long before our hearts be so, then if you please being agreed in heart, let us not wait for dreaming form, but take a little stolen delights, and so prevent our joys to come.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: If you dare speak your thoughts, I must with-draw in honour.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: The constitution of my body will never hold out
till the wedding, I must seek else where.

div.head: Actus 2. Scoen. 2.
div.stage: Enter PHYLASTER, and his boy, called BELLARIO.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: And thou shalt find her honourable, boy full of regard
Unto thy tender youth, for thy own modesty,
And for my sake, apter to give, than thou wilt be to ask,
I or deserve.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Sir, you did take me up when I was nothing,
And I am only yet something, by being yours,
sp.p: You trusted me unknown: and that which you were apt to conster: a simple innocence in me: perhaps might have been crafty: The cunning of a boy hardened in lies: and theft: yet ventured you to part my miseries and me: For which I never can expect to serve a Lady: that bears more honour in her breast than you.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: But boy, it will prefer thee, thou art young,
sp.p: And bearest a childish over-flowing love, to them that claps thy cheeks, and speak thee fair: but when judgment comes to rule those passions, thou wilt remember best those careful friends, that placed thee in the noblest way of life: she is a Princess I prefer thee to.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: In that small time that I have seen the world,
sp.p: I never knew a man hasty to part with a servant he thought trusty. I remember my father would prefer the boys he kept to greater men than he, but did it not till they were too saucy for himself.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Why gentle boy? I find no fault at all
In thy behaviour.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Sir, if I have made a fault of ignorance,
Instruct my youth, I shall be willing: if not apt to learn,
Age and experience will adorn my mind with larger
Knowledge, and if I have done a wilful fault
Think me not past all hope: for once
What master holds so strict a hand over his boy,
That he will part with him without one warning,
Let me be corrected, to break my stubbornness,
If it be so, rather than turn me off,
And I shall mend.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Thy love does plead so prettily to stay,
That trust me I could weep to part with thee:
Alas, I do not turn thee off: thou knowest it is my business
That does call thee hence, and when thou art with her,
Thou dwellest with me, think so, and it is so, and when time is full
That thou hast well discharged this heavy trust,
Laid on so weak a one: I will again with joy,
Receive thee, as I live I will, nay, weep
Not, gentle boy, it is more than time thou didst attend the Princess.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: I am gone, but since I am to part with you my Lord, and none knows whether I shall live to do more service for you, take this little prayer: Heaven bless your loves, your sighs, all your designs, may sick men if they have your wish, be well, and heavens hate those you curse, though I be one.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: The love of boys unto their Lords is strange, I have read wonders of it: yet this boy for my sake, if a man may judge by looks and speech, would out do story. I must see a day to pay him for his loyalty.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Why should these Ladies stay so long, they must
Come this way, I know the Queen employs um not,
For the reverend mother sent me word,
They would all be for the garden: if they should all
Prove honest now, I were in a fair taking:
I was never so long without sport before in my life,
And in my conscience it is not my fault.
O for our country Ladies, here is one bolted,
I will hound at her. Madam.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Your grace.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Shall I not be a trouble?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Not to me sir.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you are too quick by this sweet hand.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: You will be forsworn sir, it is an old glove, if you will talk at distance I am for you, but good Prince be not bawdy, nor do not brag, those two I only bar, and then I think I shall have sense enough to answer all the weighty Apophthegms your royal blood shall manage.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Dear Lady, can you love?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Dear Prince, how dear? I never cost you a Couch yet, nor put you to the dear repentance of a play and a banquet, here is no Scarlet sir, to make you blush, this is my own hair, and this face has been so far from being dear to any, that it never cost a penny painting, and for the rest of my poor wardrobe such as you see, it leaves no hand behind it, to make the jealous silkman's wife curse our doing.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: You much mistake me Lady.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Lord I do so, would you or I could help it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: You are very dangerous bitter, like a potion.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: No sir, I do not mean to purge you, though I mean to purge a little time on you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Do Ladies of this Country use to give no more respect to men of my full being.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.l: Full being, I understand you not, unless your grace
Means growing to fatness: and then your only remedy
Upon my knowledge Prince, is in a morning,
A cup of neat white wine, brewed with Cardus,
Then fast till supper, about five you may eat, use exercise,
And keep a sparrow hawk, you can shoot in a Tiller,
But of all, your grace must fly Phlebotomy,
Fresh pork and Conger, and clarified whey:
They are dullers of the vital animals.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Lady you talk of nothing all this time.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: It is very true sir, I talk of you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: This is a crafty wench, I like her wit well,
It will be rare to stir up a leaden appetite,
She is dainty, and must be courted with a shower of gold,
Madam look here, all these and more, then —

sp.speaker: GA.
sp.p: What have you there my Lord, gold? now as I live it is fair gold, you would have silver for it, to play with the Pages, you could not have taken me in a worse time sir, but if you have present use my Lord, I will send my man with silver, and keep your gold safe for you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Lady, Lady.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.l: Shes coming sir behind,
Will ye take white money yet for all this.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: If there be but two such in this Kingdom more, and near the Court, we may e'en hang up our harps, ten such Campher Constitutions as this would call the golden age again in question, and teach the old way for every ill fast husband, to get his own children, and what a mischief that would breed, let all consider.

Heres is another, if she be of the same last, the devil shall pluck her
on: Many fair mornings Lady.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: As many mornings, bring as many days,
fair, sweet, and hopeful to your grace.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: She gives good words yet, sure this wench is free.
If your more serious business do not call you Lady,
Let me hold quarter with you, we will talk an hour
on it quickly.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: What would your grace talk of?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Of some such pretty subject as yourself,
I will go no further than your eye, your lip, there is time enough
For one man for an Age.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Sir, they stand right, and my lips are yet even smooth,
Young enough, ripe enough, and red enough,
Or my glass wrongs me.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: O they are two twinned Cherries died in blush,
Which those fair suns above with their deep beams
Reflect upon, and ripen, sweetest beauty;
Bow down those branches, that the longing taste
Of the sweet looker on, may meet these blessings,
And taste and live.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: O delicate sweet Prince, she that hath snow enough about her heart, to take the wanton spring of ten such lines, it may be a number without Probatum. Sir, you have by such neat Poetry gathered a kiss, that if I had but five lines of that number, such pretty begging blanks: I should commend your forehead, or your cheeks, and kiss you too.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Do it in prose;
you cannot miss it Madam.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: I shall, I shall.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: By my life but you shall not,
I will prompt you first,
Can you do it now?

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Methinks it is easy now you have done it before me,
and yet I should stick at it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Stick till tomorrow, I will never part you sweetest,
but we lose time. Can you love me?

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: Love you my Lord ye?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: I will teach you in a short sentence,
Cause I will not load your memory,
This is all: Love me and lie with me.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: Was it lie with you, that you said, it is impossible.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Not to a willing mind, that will endeavour,
If I do not teach you to do it as easily in one night,
As you will go to bed: I will lose my royal blood for it.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Why Prince you have a Lady of your own,
that yet wants teaching.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: I will sooner teach a mare the old measures,
Than teach her anything belonging to the function,
She is afraid to lie with herself,
If she have but my masculine imagination about her,
I know when we are married, I must ravish her.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: By my honour that is a foul fault indeed,
But time and your good help will wear it out sir.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: And for my other I see excepting your dear self,
dearest Lady I had rather be Sir Timen a schoolmaster,
and keep a dairy maid.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: Has your grace seen the Court star Gallatea.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Out upon her, she is as cold of her favour,
as an apoplex: she sailed by but now.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: How do you hold her wit?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: I hold her wit, the strength of all the guard
Cannot hold it, if they were tied to it:
She would blow um out of the kingdom: they talk of Jupiter,
He is but a squib-cracker to her, but speak sweet Lady,
Shall I be freely welcome?

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: To your bed, if you mistrust my faith, you do me the most unnoblest wrong.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: I dare not Prince.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Make your own conditions, my purse shall seal um,
and what you dare imagine you can want,
I will furnish you withal, give worship to you thoughts
every morning about it, come I know you are bashful,
speak in my ear, will you be mine: keep this, and with
it me, soon I shall visit you.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: My Lord, my chamber is most uncertain, but when it is night I will find some means to slip into your lodging, till when

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Till when, this and my heart go with thee.

div.stage: Enter GALLATEA, from behind the Orras.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: O thou pernicious petticoat Prince, are these your vertues, well, if I do not lay a train to blow your sport up, I am no woman, and Lady Dowsabell, I will fit you for it.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Where is the boy?

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Within.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Gave you him gold to buy him clothes?

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: And has he done it?

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: It is a pretty sad talking boy, is it not, asked you his name?

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: O, you are welcome, what good news?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.l: As good as anyone can tell your grace,
that says, she has done that you would have wished.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Hast thou discovered?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: I have strained a point of modesty for you.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Aye prithee how?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: In listening after bawdry: I see, let a Lady live never so modestly, they shall be sure to find a lawful time, to hearken after bawdry, your Prince brave Pharamont was so hot on it.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Why with the Lady I suspected, I can tell the time and place.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: O when and where?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Tonight, his lodging.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Run thyself into the presence: mingle there again with other Ladies, leave the rest to me, if destiny to whom we dare not say, why thou didst this, have not decreed it so, in lasting leaves: whose smallest characters was never altered, yet this match shall break: wheres the boy.

sp.speaker: WO.
sp.p: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Sir, you are sad to change your service, is it not so?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Madam, I have not changed, I wait on you to do him service.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Then trust in me, tell me thy name.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Bellario.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Thou canst sing and play.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: If grief will give me leave Madam, I can.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Alas, what kind of grief can thy years know,
Hadst thou a cross schoolmaster when thou wentest to school?
Thou art not capable of other grief,
Thy brows and cheeks are smooth as water be,
When no breath troubles them: believe me boy,
Care seeks wrinkled brows, and hollow eyes,
And builds itself caves to abide in them,
Come sir, tell me truly, doth your Lord love me?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: I know not Madam, what it is.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Canst thou know grief, and never yet knewest love,
Thou art deceived boy, does he speak of me,
As if he wished me well?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: If it be love to forget all respect to his own friends, with thinking of your face: if it be love to sit cross armed, and think away the day, with mingling starts, and crying your name as loud as men in streets do fire: if it be love to weep himself away, when he but hears of any woman dead or killed, because it might have been your chance: if when he goes to rest, which will not be, twixt every prayer he says, to name you once as others drop beads, be to be in love, then Madam I dare swear he loves ye.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: O you are a cunning boy, and taught to your Lords credit,
But thou knowest a lie that bears this sound,
Is welcomer to me than any truth that says
He loves me not: lead the way boy, do you attend me too,
It is thy Lords business hastes me thus away.

div.stage: Enter the three Gentlewomen, MEGRA, GALLATEA, and another Lady.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p:
Come Ladies, shall we talk a round, as men do walk a mile,
women should talk an hour after supper, it is their exercise.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: It is late.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: It is all my eyes will do to lead me to my bed.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: I fear they are so heavy you will scarce find the way to your own lodging with um tonight.

div.stage: Enter PHARAMONT the Princesse boy, and a woman.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: The Prince.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Not abed Ladies, you are good sitters up, what think you of a pleasing dream to last till morning?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: I shall chose my Lord a pleasing wake before it.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: It is well you are courting of these Ladies,
is it not late Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Wait you there.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: She is jealous as I live, look my Lord,
the Princess a Hilus an Adonis,

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.p: His form is angel-like.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Why this is that, must when you are wed sit by
Your pillow, like young Appollo, with his hand
and voice, binding your thoughts in sleep, the Princess
does provide him for you, and for herself.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I find no music in these boys.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Nor I, they can do little, and that small they do,
they have not wit to hide it.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Serves he the Princess?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: It is a sweet boy, how brave she keeps him.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: Ladies all good rest, I mean to kill a buck,
tomorrow morning, ere you have done your dreams.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: All happiness attend your grace,
Gentlemen good rest, shall we to bed?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Yes, all good night.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: May your dreams be true to you,
What shall we do Gallants? it is late.
sp.stage: Enter the King, the Princesse, and a guard.
sp.l: The king is up still, see he comes,
a guard along with him.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Look your intelligence be true.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Upon my life it is, and I do hope your Highness will not tie me to a man, that in the heat of wooing, throws me off, and takes another.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: What should this mean?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: If it be true, that Lady had been better embraced cureless diseases: get you to your rest, you shall be righted: Gentlemen draw near, we shall employ ye.
Is young Pharamont come to his lodging?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: I saw him enter there.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Haste some of you, and cunningly discover,
if Megra be in her lodging.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sir she parted hence but now with other Ladies.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: If she be there, we shall not need to make a vain discovery of our suspicion, you gods I see, that who unrighteously holds wealth or state from others, shall be cursed in that which meaner men are blessed withal: Ages to come, shall know no male of him, left to inherit, and his name shall be blotted from the earth, if he have any child, it shall be crossly matched, the gods themselves shall sow willed strife betwixt her Lord and her: yet if it be your wills forgive the sin I have committed, let it not fall upon this undeserving child, if she has not broke your laws, but how could I look to be heard of gods, that must be just, praying upon the ground, I hold in wrong.

sp.speaker: LEO.
sp.p:
Sir I have asked, and her women swear she is within, but they I think are bawds, I told um I must speak with her, they laughed, and said their Lady lay speechless: I said my business was important, they said their Lady was about it: I grew hot, and cried, my business was a matter that concerned life and death, they answered so was sleeping, at which their Lady was: I urged again she had scarce time to be so, since last I saw her, they smiled again, and seemed to instruct me, that sleeping was nothing
but lying down and winking, answers more direct, I could not get from them, in short sir, she is not there.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: It is then no time to dally, you at the guard, wait at the back door of the Princes lodging, and see that none pass thence upon your lives: Knock Gentlemen, knock loud, what has your pleasure taken off your hearing: I will break your meditation, knock again, and louder, not yet, I do not think he sleeps, having such larums by him, once more, Pharamont.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What saucy groom knocks at this dead of night, where be our waiters, by my vexed soul he meets his death, that meets me for this boldness.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Prince, Prince, you wrong your thoughts, we are your friends, come down.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: The king?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: The same sir.
Come down sir, we have cause of present counsel with you,

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: If your grace please to use me, I will attend you to your chamber.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: No, it is too late Prince, I will make bold with yours.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: I have certain private reasons to myself sir,
Makes me unmannerly, and say you cannot:
Nay, press not forward, he must come through my life,
That comes here.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Sir be resolved, I must come, and will come enter.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I will not be dishonoured thus, he that enters, enters upon his death, sir it is a sign you make no stranger of me, to bring these runagates to my chamber, at these unseasoned hours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Why, do you chafe yourself: you are not wronged,
Nor shall be: only search your lodging,
For some cause to ourself, Enter I say.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I say no.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Let um enter Prince, let um enter, I am up,

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Come down.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: I dare my Lord, your hooting and your clamours, your private whispers, and your broad fleerings, can no more vex my soul, than this base carriage: but I have vengeance still in store for some, shall in the most contempt you can have of me, be joy and nourishment.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Will you come down?

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: Yes, to laugh at your worst, but I shall wring you, if my skill fail me not.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Sir, I must chide you dearly for this looseness,
You have wronged a Lady, but no more,
Conduct him to his lodging, and to bed.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Get him another wench, and you bring him to bed indeed.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: It is strange a man cannot ride a Stage or two,
To breath himself, without a warrant: if this gear hold,
That lodgings be searched thus, pray God we may lie
With our own wives in safety, that they be not
sp.stage: they come downe to the King.
sp.l: by some trick of state mistaken.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Now Lady of honour, where is your honour now?
No man can fit your palate but the Prince,
Thou most ill shrouded rottenness, thou piece
Made by a Painter and Apothecaries, thou troubled sea of lust,
Thou wilderness inhabited by willed thoughts,
Thou swollen cloud of infection, thou ripe mine of all diseases,
Thou all sin and hell, and last all devils, tell me,
Had you none to pull on with your courtesies,
But he that must be mine, and wrong my daughter:
By all the gods: all these, all the Pages, and all the Court
Shall hoot thee through the Court, fling rotten oranges:
Make rebel rhymes, and sear thy name with candles
Upon walls, do you laugh Lady Venus?

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Faith sir you must pardon me, I cannot choose but laugh,
To see you merry, if you do this O King;
Nay, if you dare do it, by all those gods you swore by,
And as many more of my own, I will have fellows,
And such fellows in it, that shall make noble mirth:
The Princess your dear daughter shall stand by me,
Upon walls, and sung in ballads, or anything, urge me no more,
I know her and her haunts, her fair leaps
And out-lying, and will discover all, and will dishonour her,
I know the boy she keeps, a handsome boy, about eighteen,
Knows what she does with him, where, when;
Come sir, you put me to a woman's madness,
The glory of a fury, and if I do not do it to the height —

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: What boy is that she raves at?

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: Alas good minded Prince, you know not these things,
I am loath to reveal um: keep this fault
As you would keep your health from the hot air
Of the corrupted people, or by heaven,
I will not sink alone, what I have known,
Shall be as public as in Print, all tongues shall speak it,
As they do the language they are born in, as free and commonly,
I will set it like a prodigious star, for all to gaze at,
And so high and glowing, that other kingdoms far and foreign,
Shall read it there, travail with it, till they find no tongue,
To make it more, nor no more people,
And then behold the fall of your fair Princess.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Has she a boy?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: So please your grace I have seen a boy wait on her, a fair boy.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Go get you to your quarters,
for this time, I will study to forget you.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.p: Do so, and I will forget your —

div.stage: Exit King, MEGRA, and the guard.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Here is a male spirit fit for Hercules.
if ever there be nine worthy of women, this wench shall ride aside and be their Captain.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Sure she has a Garrison of devils in her tongue,
She uttered such balls of willed fire, she has so nettled the King,
That all the Doctors in the Country will not cure him,
That boy was a strange found out antidote to cure her infections;
That boy, that Princess boy, that chaste, brave,
virtuous Ladies boy, and a fair boy, a well spoken boy,
All these considered can make nothing else,
But there I leave ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Nay, we will go wander with you.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: And doubtless it is true.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Aye and it is the gods
That raised this punishment to scourge the King
With his own issue, is it not a shame for all us,
That write noble in the Land for us, that should be freemen,
To behold a man that is the bravery of his age,
Phylaster: pressed down from his royal right,
By this regardless King, and only look and see the Sceptre
Ready to be cast into the hands of that lascivious Lady,
That lives in lust with a smooth boy,
Now to be married to you strange thing,
Who but that people please to let him be a Prince,
Is born a slave, in that which should be his most noble part,
His mind.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.l: That man that would not stir with you to aid Phylaster,
Let the gods forget that such a Creature
Walks upon the earth.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: The gentry do await it, and the people
against their nature, are all for him, and like a field of standing corn,
moved with a stiff gale: their heads bow all one way,

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: The only cause that draweth Phylaster back,
From this attempt, is the fair Princess love,
Which he admires, and we can now comfort.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Perhaps he will not believe.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, it is without question so.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Aye it is past speech she lives dishonestly,
But how shall we: if he be curious, work
on his belief.

sp.speaker: TRAS.
sp.p: We all are satisfied within ourselves.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Since it is true, and Lords to his own good,
I will make this new report to be my knowledge,
I will say I know it, I will swear I saw it,

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: It will be best.

sp.speaker: TRAS.
sp.p: It will move him.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: Here he comes. Good morrow to your honour:
We have spent some time in seeking you.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: My worthy friends, you that can keep your memories, to know your friend in miseries, and cannot frame on men disgrace for virtue, a good day attend you all, what service may I do worthy your acceptation.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: My Lord, we come to urge that virtue which we know
lives in your breast: forth, rise, make a head,
the nobles and the people are all dull with this usurping king,
and not a man that ever heard the word,
knows such a thing as virtue, but will second your attempts,

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: How honourable is this love in you to me,
That have deserved more, know my friends,
You that were born to shame your poor Phylaster,
With too much courtesy, I could afford to melt myself
To thanks, but my designs are not yet ripe sufficient,
That ere long I shall employ your loves,
But yet the time is short of what I would.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: The time is fuller than you expect,
That which hereafter perhaps be reached by violence,
May now be caught, as for the King you know
The people long have hated him, but now
The Princess whom they loved.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Why, what of her?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Is loathed as much as he.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: By what strange means?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: She is known a whore.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Thou liest!

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: My Lord —

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Thou liest, and thou shalt feele it, I had thought,
sp.stage: He offers to draw his sword, and is held.
sp.l: Thy mind had been of honour, than to rob a Lady
Of her good name, is an infectious sin, not to be pardoned,
Be it false as hell, it will never be redeemed,
If it be sown amongst the people, faithful to increase,
All evil they shall hear. Let me alone, that I
May cut out falsehood where it grows, set hills on hills,
Betwixt me and that man that utters this, and I will scale them all,
And from the utmost top fall on his neck,
like thunder from a cloud.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: This is most strange, sure he does love her.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: I do love fair truth, she is my mistress, and who injures her, draws vengeance from me. Sirs, let go my arms.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord be patient.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Sir, remember this is your honoured friend, that comes to do his service, and will show you why he uttered this.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I ask your pardon sir,
My zeal to truth makes me unmannerly,
sp.p: Should I have heard dishonour spoke of you, behind your backs, untruly, I had been as much distempered and enraged, as now.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: But this my Lord, is truth.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: O say not so,
sp.p: Good sir forbear to say so, it is then truth that women all are false, urge it no more, it is impossible, why should you think the Princess light?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Why she was taken at it.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: It is false, by heaven it is false, it cannot be,
Can it, speak Gentlemen? Can women all be damned?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Why then it cannot be.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: And she was taken with her boy.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What boy?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: A Page, a boy that serves her.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: O good gods, a little boy.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Aye, know you him my Lord?

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: Hell and sin know him: Sir you are deceived,
I will reason it a little milder with you,
sp.p:
If she were lustful, would she take a boy that knows not yet desires,
she would have one should meet her thoughts, and know the sin she acts, which is the great delight of wickedness, you are abused, and so is she and I.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: How, you my Lord?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Why all the worlds abused, in an unjust report.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: O noble sir, your vertues cannot look
Into the subtle thoughts of women. In short my Lord,
I took them, I, myself.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Now all the devils thou didst, fly from my rage,
Would thou hadst taken devils engendering plagues,
When thou didst take them: hide thee from mine eyes,
Would thou hadst taken daggers in thy breast,
When thou didst take them,
Or been struck dumb for ever, that this fault
might have slept in silence.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Have you known him so ill tempered?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Never before.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: The winds that are let loose from the four corners
Of the earth, and spreads themself all over sea and land,
Meets not a fair one, what friend bears a sword,
To run me through?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: Why my Lord, are you so moved at this?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: When any fall from virtue I am distracted,
I have interest in it.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: But good my Lord recall yourself,
and think what is best to be done,

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I thank you, I will do it,
Please you to leave me I will consider of it,
Tomorrow I will find your lodgings, and give you answer.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: All the gods direct you the readiest way.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I had forgot to ask um where he took her,
I will follow him. O that I had a sea within my breast,
To quench the fire I feele, more circumstances
Would but flame this fire: it more afflicts me now,
To know by whom the deed is done, than simply,
That it is done, and he that tells me this, is honourable,
As far from lies, as she is far from truth,
O that like beasts we could not grieve ourselves
With that we see not, bulls and rams will fight,
To keep their females standing in their sight,
But take them from them, and you take at once
Their spleens away, and they will fall again
Unto their pastures, growing fresh and fat,
And taste the waters of the springs as sweet as it was before.
Finding no start in sleep, but miserable man,
See, see, you gods he walks still, and the face you let him wear
When he was innocent, is still the same, not blush.
Is this justice? do you mean to entrap mortality,
That you allow treason so smooth a brow:
I cannot now think he is guilty.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Health to you my Lord:
The Princess doth commend her love, her life,
and this unto you.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: O Bellario, now I perceive she loves me,
She does show it in loving thee my boy,
She has made thee brave.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: My Lord, she has attired me past wish,
Past my desert, more fit for her attendant,
But far unfit for me that do attend.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Thou art grown Courtly my boy.
O let all women that love black deeds, learn to dissemble here,
Here, with this paper, she does write to me
As if her heart were twines of Adamant
To all the world besides, but unto me a maiden snow,
That melted with my looks: tell me my boy,
How does the Princess use thee?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Scarce like her servant, but as if I were
Something allied to her, or had preserved her life
Three times by my fidelity: as mothers fond,
Do use their only sons, as I would use one that is left unto my trust,
For whom my life should pay,
If he meet harm: so she does use me.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Why it is wondrous well,
But what kind language does she feed thee with?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Why she does tell me she will trust my youth with all her maiden store, and does call me her pretty servant, bids me weep no more for leaving you, she will see my service rewarded, and such words of that soft strain, that I am nearer weeping when she ends, than ere she speaks.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: This is much better still.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Are you not well my Lord?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Ill, no Bellario.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Methinks your words fall out from your tongue, so unevenly, nor is there in your looks that quickness that I was wont to see.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Thou art deceived boy. And she strokes thy head.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And she does clap thy cheeks.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: She does my Lord.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: And she does kiss thee boy, ha.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: How my Lord?

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: She kisses thee.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Never my Lord, by heaven.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: That is strange, I know she does.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: No by my life.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: Why then she does not love me,

Come she does, I bid her do it: I charged her by all charms of love between us, by the hope of peace we should enjoy, to yield thee all delight, naked as to her Lord. I took her oath thou shouldst enjoy her. Tell me gentle boy, is she not paradise: is not her breath sweet as Arabian winds when fruits are ripe, are not her breasts two liquid Ivory balls? is she not all a lasting mine of joy?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Yes, now I see why my discurled thoughts were so perplexed. When first I went to her my heart held auguries: you are abused, some villain has abused you, I do see where you tend. Fall rocks upon his head, that put this to you, it is some subtle train to bring that noble friend of yours to naught.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p:
Thou thinkst I will be angry with thee, come thou shalt know all my drift. I hate her more than I love happiness, and placed thee there to pry with sparrows eyes, into her deeds, hast thou
discovered, is she fallen to lust, as I would wish her, speak some comfort to me.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: My Lord you did mistake the boy you sent,
Had she the lust of sparrows and of goats,
Had she a sin that weighed from the world, beyond the name of lust,
I would not aid her base desires,
But what I come to know as servant to her,
I would not reveal, to make my life last ages.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: O my heart!
This is a salve worse than the main deceit,
Tell me thy thoughts, for I will know the least
That dwells within thee, or will rip thy heart,
To know it, I will see thy thoughts as plain,
As I do now thy face.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Why so you do: she is for aught I know, by all the gods,
As chaste as ice: but were she foul as hell,
And I did know it thus, the breath of Kings,
The points of swords, tortures, nor bulls of brass,
Should wrack it from me.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Then it is no time to dally with thee, I will take thy life,
For I do hate thee, I could curse thee now.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: If you do hate me, you could not curse me worse,
The gods have not a punishment in store,
To me, than is your hate.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Fie, fie, so young and so dissembling, tell me when and where,
Thou didst enjoy her, or let plagues fall upon me,
If I destroy thee not.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: By heaven I never did, and when I lie to save my life,
May I live long and loathed, hew me asunder,
And whilst I can think, I will love those pieces you have cut away
Better than those that grow, and kiss those limbs
Because you made um so.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Fearest thou not death, can boys contemn that.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: O! what boy is he could be content to live
To be a man, that sees the best of men thus passionate,
Thus without reason.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O thou dost not know what it is to die.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Yes, I do know my Lord it is less than to be born,
A lasting sleep, a quiet resting from all jealousy,
A thing we all pursue: I know besides, it is but giving over again,
That must be lost.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: But there are pains false boy,
For perjured, souls: think but those, and then thy heart will melt,
And then thou wilt utter all.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: May they fall all upon me, whilst I live,
If I be perjured, or have ever thought of that you charge me with,
sp.p: If I be false, send me to suffer in those punishments you speak of Kill me.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O! What should I do, why who can but believe him?

He does swear so earnestly, that if it were not true, the gods would not endure him. Rise Bellario, thy protestations are so deep, and thou dost look so truly when thou utterest them, that though I knew um false, as were my hopes, I cannot urge thee further, but thou wert too blame to envy me: for I must love thy honest looks, and take no revenge upon thy honest looks: a love from me to thee is firm, whatever thou dost, it troubles me, that I have called thy blood out of thy cheeks, that did so well become thee: But good boy let me not see thee more, something is done, that will distract me, that will make me mad, if I behold thee, if thou tenderest me, let me not see thee.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: I will fly as far,
sp.p: As there is morning, ere I give distaste to that most honoured frame, but through these tears shed at my hapless parting, I can see a world of treason practised upon you, and her, and me, farewell for evermore, if you shall hear that sorrows struck me dead, and after find me loyal, let there be a tear shed from you, in my memory, and I shall rest at peace.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Blessing be with thee whatever thou deservest.
O where shall I go bathe this body, nature too unkind,
That madest no medicine to a troubled mind.

sp.speaker: PRIN,
sp.l: I marvel my boy comes not back,
But that I know my love will question him over and over,
How I slept, make talk how I remember him,
When his dear name was last spoken,
And how spoke when I sight song, and ten thousand such,
I should be angry at his stay.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: What, in your meditations, who attends you?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: None but my single self, I need no guard,
I do no wrong, nor fear none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Tell me, have you not a boy?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: What kind of boy?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: A page, a waiting boy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: A handsome boy?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: I think he be not ugly Sir, well
qualified, and dutiful, I know him,
I took him not for beauty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: He speaks, and sings, and plays?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: About eighteen?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: I never asked his age.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Is he full of service?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: By your pardon, why do you ask?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Put him away.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Put him away I say, has done you that good service,
Shames me to speak off.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Good sir, let me understand you?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: If you fear me, show it in duty? put away that boy.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Let me have reason for it, and then your will is a command.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Do not you blush to ask it, cast him off:
Or I shall do that shame to you, ye are one shame with me,
And so near my self, that by the gods,
I would dare not tell myself, what you myself,
Have done.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: What I have done?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: It is a new language, that all love to learn:
The common people speak it well already,
They need no grammar: understand me well, there be foul
sp.p: Whispers stirring, cast him off, and suddenly do it, farewell.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Where may a maid live securely free,
Keeping her honour fair, not with the living,
They feed upon opinions, errors, dreams, and make um truth,
They draw a nourishment out of defamings,
Grow upon disgraces, and when they see a virtue fortified,
Strongly above the battery of their tongues.
O how they mind to sink it, and defeated foul
Sick with poison, strike the mountains,
Where noble names be sleeping, till they sweat,
And the cold Marble melt.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Peace to your fairest thoughts, dearest mistress.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: O my dearest servant,
I have a war within me.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: He must be more than man that makes these crystals run into rivers, sweetest fair the cause, and as I am your slave, tied to your goodness, your creature made again from what I was, and newly spirited, I will right your honour.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: O my best love, that boy.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What boy?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: The pretty boy you gave me,

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Must be no more mine.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: They are jealous of him.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Jealous, who?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: The King.

sp.speaker: PHI,
sp.l: O my misfortune,
Then it is no idle jealousy, let him go.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: O cruel, are you hard hearted too?
Who shall now tell you how much I loved you?
Who shall swear it to you, and weep the tears I send?
Who shall now bring you letters, rings, bracelets,
Lose his health in service, make tedious nights,
In stories of your praise? Who shall now sing
Your crying Elegies, and strike a sad soul
Into senseless pictures, and make them warm?
Who shall take up his lute, and touch it,
Till he crown a silent sleep upon my eye-lids,
Make me dream and cry:
O my dear, dear Phylaster.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: O my heart, would he had broken thee,
That made thee know this Lady was not loyal.
Mistress forget the boy, I will get you a far better.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: O never, never, such a boy again, as my Bellario.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: It is but your fond affection.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: With thee, my boy, fare well for ever,
All service in servants, farewell faith and all
Desires to do well, for thy sake, let all that
Shall succeed thee, for thy wrongs,
Sell and betray chaste love.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And all this passion for a boy.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: He was your boy, and you put him unto me,
And the loss of such must have a mourning for.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O thou forgetful woman.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: How, my Lord?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: False Arethusa.
Hast thou a medicine to restore my wits,
When I have lost um, if not,
leave to talk, and do thus.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Do what sir, would you sleep?
For ever Arethusa, O ye gods, ye gods:
Give me a wealthy patience, have I stood naked
Above the shock of many fortunes? have I seen mischief,
Numberless, and mighty, grow like a sea upon me:
Have I taken danger as deep as death, into my bosom,
And laughed upon it, made it but a mirth,
And flowing it by, do I live now like him under this tyrant King,
That languishing hear his sad bell, and sees his Mourners,
Do I bear all this bravely? and sink at length
Under a woman's falsehood, O that boy, that cursed boy,
None but a villain boy, to ease your lust.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Nay, then I am betrayed,
sp.l: I feele the plot cast for my overthrow:
O I am wretched.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Now you may take that little right I have to this
sp.l: Poor Kingdom, give it to your Joy, for I have no joy in it:
Some far place, where never woman kind durst set her foot,
For bursting with her poison must I seek,
And live to curse you, and there dig a Cave,
And preach to beasts and birds, what women are;
How Heaven is in your eyes, but in your hearts more hell,
Than hell has: How your tongues, like Scorpions,
Both heal and poison: How your thoughts woven,
With thousand changes in one subtle web, and worn by you:
How that foolish men that read the story of a woman's face,
And dies believing it is lost for ever: How all the good you have,
Is but a shadow, in the morning with you, and at night behind you,
Past and forgotten: How your vows are frost fast, for a night,
And with the next Sun gone; How you are,
Being taken altogether.
A mere confusion, and so dead a Chaos,
That love cannot distinguish these sad texts,
Till my last hour I am bound to utter of you,
So farewell all my woe, all my delight.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Be merciful you gods, and strike me dead.
sp.l: What way have I deserved this? make my breast transparent,
That the world jealous of me,
May see the foulest thought my heart holds:
Where shall women turn their eyes to find out constancy?
Save me, how black and vile methinks, that boy looks now!
O thou dissembler, that before thou spokest,
Wert in thy cradle false, sent to make lies,
And to betray innocence, thy Lord and thou
Mayst glory in the ashes of a maid, fooled by her passion:
But the conquest is nothing so great as wicked,
Fly away, let my command force thee to that,
Which shame would do without it, if thou understoodest.
The loathed office thou hast undertook,
Why thou wouldst hide thee under heaps of hills,
Lest we should dig and find thee.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: O what god angry with me, hath sent this strange disease
Into the noblest minds, Madam this grief you add unto me,
Is no more than drops to seas, for which they are not seen to swell,
My Lord has struck his anger through my heart,
And let out all the hope of future joys,
Ye need not bid me fly, I came to part,
To take my latest leave,
Farewell for ever.
I durst not run away in honesty from such a Lady,
Like a boy that stole, or made some greater fault,
The power of gods assist you in your suffering:
Hasty time reveal the truth to your abused Lord, and mine,
That he may know your worth, whilst I go seek
Out some forgotten place to die.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Peace guide thee, thou hast overthrown me once,
But if I had another time to lose,
Thou, or another villain with thy looks,
Might take me out of it, and send me naked,
My hair disheveled, through the fiery streets.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Madam, the king would hunt,
And calls for you with earnestness.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: I am in tune to hunt: Diana if thou canst
Rage with a maid, as with a man, let me discover thee
bathing, and turn me to a fearful hind,
That I may die pursued by cruel hounds,
And have my story written in my wounds.

div.head: Actus 4. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter the King, PHARAMONT, Princesse, MEGRA, GALLATEA, LEON. CLE. TRA. and two Wood-men.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What, are the hounds before, and all the Woodmen?
Our horses ready, and our bows bent?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: All sir.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: You are cloudy sir. Come we have forgotten your venial trespasses, let not that sit heavy upon your spirit,
Here is none dares utter it.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: He looks like an old surfeited stallion after his leaping, Dull as a Dormouse: see how he sinks, the wench has shot him between wind and water, and I hope sprung a lake.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: He needs no teaching, he strikes sure enough,
His greatest fault is, he hunts too much in the purlieus,
Would he would leave off poaching.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: And for his horn, has left it at the lodge where he lay late: O he is a pernicious lime-hound, turn him upon the pursue of any Lady, and if he lose her, hang him up in the slip: when my fox bitch beauty grows proud, I will borrow him.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Is your boy turned away?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: You did command sir, and I obeyed you.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: It is well done, hark ye further.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Is it possible this fellow should repent,
Methinks that were not noble in him,
And yet he looks like a mortified member,
As if he had a sick man's salve in his mouth,
If a worse man had done this fault now,
Some physical Justice or other, would presently
Without the help of an Almanac,
Have opened the obstructions of his liver,
And let him blood with a dog-whip.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.l: See, see, how modestly yon Lady looks,
As if she came from churching with her neighbours,
Why what a devil can you see in her face,
But that she is honest.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Faith no great matter to speak of: a foolish twinkling with the eye, that spoils her coat, but he must be a cunning Herald that finds it.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: See how they muster one another, O there is a rank regent, where the devil carries the Colours, and his damned drum major. Now the flesh and the world come behind with the Carriage.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sure this Lady has a good turn done against her will, before she was common talk, now none dares say Cantharides can stir her, her face looks like a warrant, willing and commanding all tongues, as they will answer it, to be tied up, and bolted, when this Lady means to let herself loose, as I live, she has got a goodly protection, and a gracious: and may use her body discreetly, for her health sake, once a week, except lent and dog-days. O if they were to be got for money, what a large sum would come out of the City, for these Licences.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: To horse, to horse, we lose the morning Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p: What, have you lodged the Dear below?

div.stage: Exit King and Lords, Manet Wood-men.

sp.speaker: 2 WOOD.
sp.p: Yes, they are ready for the bow.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p: Who shoots?
The Princess.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p: No, she will hunt.

sp.speaker: 2 WOOD.
sp.p: She will take a stand I say.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p: Who else?

sp.speaker: 2 WOOD.
sp.p: Why the young strange Prince.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.l: He shall shoot in a stone bow for me,

sp.speaker: 2 WOOD.
sp.p: The Lady Gallatea.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p: That is a good wench, an she would not chide us for tumbling of her women in the brakes, she is liberal, and by the gods, they say honest, and whether that be a fault or no, I have nothing to do, there is all.

sp.speaker: 2 WOOD.
sp.p: No, one more, Megra.

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p:
