That is a firker I'faith boy, there is a wench will ride her haunches as hard after a kennel of hounds as a hunting saddle, and when she comes home, get um clapped, and all is well again, I have known her lose herself three times in one afternoon, if the Woods had
been answerable, and has been work enough for one man to find her, and has sweat for it: she rides well, and she pays well, hark else.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.l: O that I had been nourished in the woods,
With milk of goats, and Acorns, and not known
The right of Crowns, nor the dissembling trains
Of cruel love: but digged myself a Cave,
Where I, my fire, my Cattle and my bed,
Might have been shut together in one shed,
And then had taken me some mountain girl,
Beaten with winds, chaste as the rock whereon she dwelt,
That might have strewed my bed with leaves and reeds,
And with the skins of beasts our neighbours, and have born
Out her big breasts, my large course issue:
This had been a life free from vexation.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: O! wicked men, an innocent may walk safe amongst beasts,
Nothing assaults me here, I see my grieved Lord, sits as
His soul were searching out a way to leave his body.
Pardon me that brake thy last commandment, for I must speak:
You that are grieved can pity; hear my Lord.

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: Is there a creature yet so miserable that I can pity?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: O my noble Lord, view my strange fortunes,
And bestow on me according to your bounty,
If my service can merit nothing, so much as may serve to keep
That little piece I hold of life, from cold and hunger.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Now by the gods this is unkindly done, to vex me
With thy sight, thou art fallen again to thy dissembling trade,
How shouldst thou think to cozen me again,
Remains there yet a plague untried for me. Even so
Thou weepest, and lookest, and spokest, when I first took thee,
Curse on the time. If thy commanding tears can work
On any other, use thy art, I will not betray it, which way
Wilt thou take, that I may shun thee, for thine eyes are
Poison to mine, and I am loath to grow in rage:
This way or that way?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Any will serve, but I will choose to have
That path in chase, that leads unto my grave.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: This is the strangest sudden chance, you Wood-man.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: My Lord Leon —

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Saw you a Lady come this way, on a sable horse, star-eyed with stars of white?

sp.speaker: 1 WOOD.
sp.p: Was she not young and tall?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Yes, rode she to the wood, or to the plain?

sp.speaker: 2 WOOD.
sp.p: Faith my Lord, we saw none.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Pox of your questions then: What, is she found?

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Nor will be, I think.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Let him seek his daughter himself, she cannot stray
About a little necessary natural business:
But the whole Court must be in arms,
When she has done, we shall have peace.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: There is already a thousand fatherless tales amongst us,
Some say, her horse run away with her; some, a wolf pursued her;
Others, it was a plot to kill her, and that armed men were seen
In the wood: but questionless, she rode away willingly.

div.stage: Enter the King, TRA. and ther Lords.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Howe is that? answer me so again.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sir, shall I lie?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes, lie, and damn, rather than tell me that:
I say again, where is she? mutter not,
Sir, speak you, where is she?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sir, I do not know.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Speak that again so boldly, and by heaven it is thy last. You fellows, answer me, where is she? mark me all, I am your king, I wish to see my daughter, show her me, I do command you all, as you are subjects, to show her me: what, am I not your king, if I, why then, am I not to be obeyed?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Yes, if you command things possible, and honest.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Things possible, and honest, hear me then, thou traitor, that darest confine thy king, to possible and honest, things show her me, or let me perish, if I cover not all Cycele with blood.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Faith I cannot, unless you will tell me where she is.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: You have betrayed me, you have let me loose the Jewel of my life, go bring her me, and set her here before me, it is the king will have it so, whose breath can still the winds, uncloud the Sun, charm down the swelling sea, and stop the Floods of heaven: speak, can it not?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: No, cannot the breath of a king do this?

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: No more smell sweet itself, if once the lungs be but corrupted.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Take you heed?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Take you heed, how you dare the powers
That must be just.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Alas! What are we kings, why do you gods
Place us above the rest, to be served, flattered, and adored,
Still we believe we hold within our hands your Thunder,
And when we come to try the power we think we have,
There is not a leaf shakes at our threatenings,
I have sinned, it is true, and here I stand to be punished,
Yet would not these be punished, let me choose my way,
And lay it on.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: He articles with the gods, would somebody would draw bonds, for the performance of covenant betwixt them.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: What, is she found?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: No, we have taken her horse, he galloped empty by, there is some treason: you Gallatea rode into the Wood with her, Why left you her?

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: She did command me.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Command, you should not.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.l: It would ill become my fortunes, and my birth,
To disobey the daughter of my king.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: O you are all cunning to obey us, for our hurts,
But I will have her.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: If I have her not, by this sword, there shall be no more Cycele.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: What, will he carry it to Spaine in his pockets?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: I will not leave one man alive,
But the king, a Cook, and a Taylor.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Yes, you may do well to leave your Lady bedfellow here for a spinster.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: I see the injuries I have done, must be revenged.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sir, this is not the way to find her out.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Run all, disperse yourselves, the man that finds her, or if she be killed, the traitor, I will make him great.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Aye, some would give five thousand pounds to find her.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Come, let us seek.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Each man a several way, here I myself.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, we here.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Lady, you must go search too.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: I had rather be the search myself.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Where am I now, feet find out the way, without the counsel of my troubled head, I will follow you boldly about these woods, or mountains, through brambles, pits and floods; Heaven I hope will ease me, I am sick.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Yonder my Lady is, gods knows, I want nothing, because I do not wish to live, yet I will try her charity. O hear you, that have plenty from that flowing store, drop some on dry grounds, see the lively red is gone to guard her heart: I fear she faints, Madam, look up: she breathes not; open once those rosie twines, and send unto my Lord your latest farewell: O she stirs; How is it Madam? speak comfort.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: It is not gently done to put me in a miserable life, and hold me there, I prithee let me go, I shall do best without thee.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I am too blame to be so much in rage,
I will tell her coolly, when and where I heard
This killing truth, I will be temperate in speaking,
And as just in hearing; O monstrous, tempt me not
sp.p: You gods, good gods, tempt not a frail man, who is he that has a heart, but he must ease it with his tongue.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: My Lord, help, help the Princess.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: I am well, forbear.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Let me love lightnings, let me be embraced and kissed
By Scorpions, or adore the eyes of Basilisks,
Rather than trust the tongues of hell-bread women:
Some good god look down, and shrink these veins up,
Stick me here a stone, lasting to memory of this damned act.
Hear me you wicked ones, you have put hills of fire
Into my breast, not to be quenched with tears,
For which may guilt sit on your bosoms, at your meals and beds,
Despair await you, what, before my face,
Poison of Asps between your lips, diseases be your best issues,
Nature make a curse and throw it on you.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Dear Phylaster, leave to enrage, and hear me.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I have done,
Forgive my passion, not the calmed sea, when Eolus
Locks up his windy brood, is less disturbed than I,
I will make you know, dear Arethusa, take this sword,
And search how temperate a heart I have, then you,
And this your boy, may live and reign in lust, without control.
Wilt thou Bellario, I prithee kill me,
Thou art poor, and mayst nourish ambitious thoughts
When I am dead, thy way were freer, am I raging now?
If I were mad, I should desire to live: Sirs, feele my pulse,
Whether you have known a man in more
Equal tune to die.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, your pulse keeps madmen's time,
So does your tongue.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: You will not kill me then?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Kill you,

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I blame not thee Bellario, thou hast done but that
Which gods would have transformed themselves to do,
Be gone, leave me without reply, this is the last
Of all our meetings, kill me with this sword, be wise,
sp.p: Or worse will follow, we are two, earth cannot bear at once, resolve to do or suffer.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: If my fortunes be so good to let me fall upon thy hand,
I shall have peace with earth,
sp.p: Yet tell me this, there will be no slanders, no jealousy, in the other world no ill here?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Show me the way to joy.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Then guide my feeble hand, you that have power
To do it, for I must perform a piece of Justice:
If your youth have any way offended heaven,
Let prayers short and effectual, reconcile you to it.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: I am prepared,

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.l: I will see the king if he be in the Forest,
I have hunted him this two hours, if I should come home,
And not see him, my sisters would laugh at me,
I can see nothing but people, better horsed than myself,
That out ride me, I can hear nothing but shouting,
These kings had need of strong brains,
The whooping would put a man out of his wits:
sp.p: There is a Courtier with his sword drawn, by this hand upon a woman, I think.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Are you at peace?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: With heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Nay, they divide thy soul and body.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: Hold dastard, strike a woman, thou art a craven, I warrant thee, thou wouldst be loath to play half a dozen venies at wasters with a man for a broken head.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Leave us good friend.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: What ill bred man art thou, to intrude thyself upon our private sports, our recreations.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.l: God judge me, I understand you not,
But I know the rogue has hurt ye.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Pursue thy own affairs, it will be ill to multiply blood upon my head, which thou wilt force me to.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: I know not your Rhetoric, but I can lay it on if you touch the woman.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Slave, take what thou deservest,

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Gods guard my Lord.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: O, do you breath?

sp.speaker: PHY.
sp.p: I hear the tread of people, I am hurt, the gods take part against me, would this bore have held me thus else: I must shift for life, though I do lose it, I would find a course,
To lose it rather by my will, than force.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.l: I cannot follow the rogue,
I prithee wench come kiss me now.

div.stage: Enter PHARAMONT, LEON, CLE. TRA. and Wood-men.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What art thou.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.l: Almost killed I am, for a foolish woman,
A knave has hurt her.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: The Princess Gentlemen. Wheres the wound Madam,
Is it dangerous.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: He has not hurt me.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: By god she lies, has hurt her in the breast, look else.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O secret spring of innocent blood.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: It is above wonder, who should dare this.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: I felt it not.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Speak villain, who has hurt the Princess?

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: Is it the Princess?

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: Then I have seen something yet.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: But who has done it?

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: I told you a rogue, I never saw him before, I.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Madam, who did it?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Some dishonest wretch, alas I know him not,
And do forgive him.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: He is hurt too, he cannot go far, I let my fathers old fox fly about his ears.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: How, will you have me kill him?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Not at all, it is some distracted fellow.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: By this air, I will leave never a piece bigger than a nut, and bring him all in my hat.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p:
Nay, good sir, if you do take him, bring him quick to me,
and I will study for a punishment great as his sin.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: But swear.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: By all my Love, I will: Wood-man, conduct the Princess unto the king, and bear that wounded fellow to dressing: Come Gentlemen, we will follow the chase close.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: I pray you friend, let me see the king.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: That you shall, and receive thanks.

sp.speaker: COVN.
sp.p: If I get clear of this, I will see no more gay fights,

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: O heavens! heavy death sits on my brow,
And I must sleep, bear me thou gentle bank,
For ever if thou wilt, you sweet on all,
Let me unworthy press you, I could wish,
I rather were a Corse strewed over with you,
Than quick above you, dullness shuts my eyes, and I am giddy,
That I could take so sound a sleep,
That I might never wake.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I have done ill, my conscience calls me false,
To strike at her that would not strike at me,
When I did fight, methought I heard her pray,
The gods to guard me, she may be abused,
And I a loathed villain if she be, she will conceal
Who hurt her, he has wounds, and cannot follow,
Neither knows he me. Who is this? Bellario sleeping,
If thou be-est guilty, there is no justice that thy sleep
Should be so sound, and mine whom thou hast wronged,
So broken.
Hark I am pursued, you gods I will take
This offered means of my escape.
They have no mark to know me, but my blood,
If she be true, if false, let mischief
Light on all the world at once.
Sword print my wounds upon his sleeping body,
He has none I think are mortal,
Nor would I lay greater on thee.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: O! death I hope is come, blessed be that hand, it wished me well again for pity.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I have caught myself,
The loss of blood hath stayed my flight here,
Here is he that struck thee, take thy full revenge,
Use me as I did mean thee, worse than death:
I will teach thee to revenge. This luckless hand
Wounded the Princess, tell my followers, thou
Didst receive these hurts in staying me,
And I will second thee: get a reward.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Hide, hide my Lord, and save your self.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How is this? wouldst thou I should be safe?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Else it were vain for me to live.
These wounds I have, has not bled much,
Reach me that noble hand, I will help to cover you.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Art thou then true to me?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Or let me perish loathed: Come my Lord,
Creep in amongst these bushes, who does know
But that the gods may save your breath in it, Shromd,

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Then I shall die for grief, if not for this,
That I have wounded thee: What wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Shift for myself: Well, peace, I hear um come.

sp.speaker: WITHIN.
sp.p: Follow, follow, that way they went.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: With my own wounds I will bloody my own sword,
I need not counterfeit to fall, heaven knows,
I can stand no longer.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: To this place I tract him by his blood.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Yonder my Lord, creeps one away.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Stay sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: A wretched creature, wounded in these woods by beasts,
Relieve me, if your names be men,
Or I shall perish.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.l: This is he my Lord, upon my soul that hurt her,
It is the boy, that wicked boy, that served her.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O thou damned in thy creation, what cause couldst thou shape to strike the Princess?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Then I am betrayed,

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Betrayed, no, apprehended.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: I confess, urge it no more, that big with evil thoughts,
I set upon her, and did make my aim her death:
For charity let fall at once, the punishment you mean.
And do not load this weary flesh with torture,

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I will know who hired thee to this deed.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: My own revenge.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Revenge, for what?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: It pleased her to receive me as her Page,
And when my fortunes ebbed, that men stride over them careless.
She did shower her welcome graces on me,
And did swell my fortunes: till they overflowed
Their banks, threatening the men that crossed them,
When as swift as storms arise at sea, she turned
Her eyes to burning Suns upon me, and did dry the streams
She had bestowed, leaving me worse, and more contemned
Than other little brooks, Because I had been great,
In short, I knew I could not live:
And therefore did desire to die revenged.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.l: If tortures can be found, long as thy natural life,
Resolve to feele the utmost vigour.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Help to lead him hence.

div.stage: PHILASTER creepes out of a bush.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Turn back you ravishers of innocents,
Know you the price of what you bear away
So rudely.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: My Lord Phylaster.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: It is not the treasure of all the Kings in one,
The wealth of Tagus, nor the rocks of pearl,
That pave the Court of Neptune, can weigh down
That virtue. It was I that hurt the Princess,
Place me some god, on a Pyramades, higher than
Hills of earth: and lend a voice loud as you
Thunder to me, that from thence I may teach
The under-world, the worth that dwells in him.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: My Lord, some man weary of life that would be glad to die.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Leave this untimely courtesy Bellario.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Alas, he is mad, come, will you bear me hence?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: By all the oaths that men ought most to keep,
And gods to punish most, when men do break.
He touched her not, take heed Bellario,
How thou dost drown the vertues thou hast shown,
With perjury, by all the gods it was I,
You know she stood betwixt me and my right.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Thy own tongue be thy Judge.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: It was Phylaster.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.l: Is it not a brave boy?
Well, I fear me sir, we were deceived.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Have I no friend here?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Then show it some good body, lend a hand to draw us nearer: Would you have tears shed for you, when you die? then lay me gently on his neck, that there I may weep floods, and breath forth my spirit. Not all the wealth of Pluto, nor the gold locked in the heart of earth, can buy away this from me; this had been a ransom to have redeemed the , had he been taken; you hard-hearted men, more stony than these Mountains, can you see such a clear pure blood drop, and not cut your flesh to stop his life, to bind whose bitter wounds, Queens ought to tear their hairs, and with their tears bathe them: forgive me thou that art the wealth of poor Phylaster,

div.stage: Enter the King, Princesse, and a guard.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Is the villain taken?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Sir, here be two confess the deed, but suit it was Phylaster.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Question it no more, it was.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: The fellow that did fight with him, will tell us that.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Aye me, I know him well.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Did not you know him?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Sir, if it were he, he was disguised.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I was so: O my stars, that I should live still.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Thou ambitious fool, thou that hast laid a train for thy own life, now I do mean to do, I will leave to talk, bear them to prison.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Sir, they did plot together, to take hence this harmless life, should it pass unrevenged, I should to earth, weeping. Grant me then, by all the loves a father bears his child, their custodies, that I may appoint their tortures, and their deaths.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Death, soft your law will not reach that for this fault.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: It is granted, take um to you with a guard.
Come Princely Pharamont, this business past,
We shall with more security go on
With our intended match.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: I pray that this action lose not Phylastor the hearts of the people.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.l: Fear it not, their oer-wise heads
Will think it but a trick.

div.head: Actus 5. Scoen. 1.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Has the king sent for him to death?

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Yes, but the king must know, it is not in his power to war with heaven.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: We linger time, the king sent for Phylastor, and the headsman, an hour ago.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Are all his wounds well?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: All, they were but scratches, but the loss of blood made him faint.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: We dally Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: We will shuffle hard before he perish.

div.stage: Enter PHYLASTER, Princesse, BOY, in prison.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Nay, faith Phylaster, grieve not, we are well.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord forbear, we are wondrous well.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: O Arethusa and Bellario,
Leave to be kind, I shall be shut from heaven,
If you continue so, I am a man false to a pair
Of the truest ones that ever earth bore.
Can it bear us all? forgive me, and leave me;
But the King hath sent to call me to my death,
O show it me, and then forget me: and for thee my boy,
I shall deliver words, will mollify the hearts of beasts,
To spare thy innocence.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Alas, my Lord: My life is not a thing worthy
Your noble thoughts, it is not a life, it is but a piece
Of child-hood thrown away: should I out live you,
I should out live virtue and honour:
And when that day come, if ever I shall close
These eyes but once; may I live spotted for my perjury,
And waste by time to nothing.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: And I the woefullest maid that ever lived,
Forced with my hands to bring my Lord to death,
Do by the honour of a Virgin swear.
To tell no hour behind it.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Make me not hated so.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Come from this prison, all joyful to our deaths.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: People will tear me, when they find you true,
To such a wretch as I, I shall die loathed.
Enjoy your Kingdom peaceably, whilst I for ever sleep,
Forgotten with my faults. Every just maiden, every maid in love,
Will have a piece of me, if you be true.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: My dearest, say not so.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: A piece of you, he was not born of woman, that can cut it, and look on.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Take me in tears betwixt you,
For my heart will break with shame and sorrow.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Why? it is well.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Lament no more.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Why? what would you have done?
If you had wronged me basely, and had found
My life no whit compared to yours for love,
Sirs, deal with me truly.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: It was mistaken Sir.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Why, if it were?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Then sir we would have asked you pardon.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And have hope to enjoy it.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Enjoy it, Aye.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Would you indeed? be plain.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: We would my Lord.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Forgive me then.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: It is as it should be now.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Lead to my death.

div.stage: Enter the King, LEON; CLE. TRA. and a guard.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Gentlemen, who saw the Prince?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: So please you Sir, he is gone to see the City,
And the new Plot-form, with some Gentlemen
Attending on him.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Is the Princess ready to bring her prisoner out?

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: She waits your grace.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Tell her we stay.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: King, you may be deceived yet, the head you aim at,
Cost more setting on, then to lose it so lightly:
If it must off like a willed over-flow, that sweeps before him,
A golden stock, and with it shakes down bridges,
Cracks the strong hearts of Pines, whose cable roots
Held out a thousand storms, a thousand thunders,
And so made weightier, takes whole villages upon his back,
And in the heat of pride charges strong Towns,
Towers, Castles, Palaces, and leaves them desolate.
So shall thy head, thy noble head, bury the lives
Of thousands, that must bleed with thee like a sacrifice,
In thy red ruins.

div.stage: Enter PHI. Princesse, BOY, with a garland of flowers on's head.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: How now, what mask is this?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Right royal Sir,
sp.p:
I shall sing you an Epithalamion, but having lost my best aires with my fortunes, and wanting a celestial harp to strike this blessed union; thus in glad story I give you all these two fair Cedar branches.
The noblest of the mountains where they grew, straightest and tallest, under whose still shades, the worthier beasts have made their layers, and slept free from the fervor of the Serian star, and the fell thunder-stroke, free from the Clouds, when they were big with humour, and deliver in thousand spouts, that issues to the earth: O there was none but silent quiet there, till never-pleased fortune shot up shrubs base under branches, to devour these branches, and for a while they did so, and did reign over the Mountain, and did choake up his beauty with brakes, rude, thorns and thistles, till the Sun scorched them to the root, and dried um there, and now a gentle gale has blown again, that made these branches meet and twine together, never to be unarmed: The god that sings his Number over marriage beds, has knit their noble hearts, and here they stand, your children, worthy king, and I have done.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Sir, if you love it in plain truth, for now there is no masking in it, this gentleman the prisoner that you gave me, is become my keeper.
And through all the bitter threats, your Jealousies, and his ill fate, have wrought him, thus nobly hath he struggled, and at length arrived here:
My dear husband.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Your dear husband. Call in the Captain of the Citadel, where you shall keep your wedding, I will provide a mask shall make your Hymen turn his saffron into a sullen coat, and sing sad requiems to your departing souls, blood shall put out your torches, and instead of gaudy flowers about your wanton necks, an Axe shall hang, like a prodigious Meteor, ready to crop your loves sweets. Hear you gods: From this time do I shake all title off of father to this woman, this base woman, and what there is of venge in a Lyon chased amongst dogs, or robbed of his dear young, the same enforced more terrible, more mighty, look from me.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.l: Sir, by that little life that I have left to swear by,
There is nothing can stir me from myself.
What I have done, I have done, without repentance,
For death to me can be no bugbear, as long as Pharamont,
Is not my heads-man.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Sweet peace upon thy soul thou worthy maid,
sp.p: Whenever thou diest, for this time I will excuse thee over by thy prologue.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Sir, let me speak next,
And let my dying words be better with you
Then my dull living actions: If you aim at the life
Of this sweet innocent, you are a tyrant and a savage monster,
That feeds upon the blood you gave a life to,
Your memory shall be as foul behind you as you are living:
All your better deeds shall be in water writ;
But this in marble. No Chronicle shall speak you,
Though your own, but for a shame of men:
No Monument, though high and big as Pelion,
Shall be able to cover this base murder, make it rich with brass,
Gold and shining Jasper, like the Pyramids;
Lay on Epitaphs, such as make great men gods,
My little Marble, that only clothes my ashes, not my faults,
Shall far out shine it: and for after issues,
Think not so madly of the heavenly wisdoms,
That they will give you more, for your mad rage to cut off:
Unless it be some snake, or something like yourself,
That in his birth shall strangle you: Remember my father king,
There was a fault, but I forgive it, let that sin
Persuade you to love this Lady, if you have a soul.
Think, save her and be saved, for myself, I have so long
Expected this glad hour, so languished under you,
And daily withered, that by the gods, it is a joy to die,
I find a recreation in it.

sp.speaker: MES.
sp.p: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: MES.
sp.l: Get to your strength,
And rescue the Prince Pharamont from danger,
He is taken prisoner by the Citizens,
For the Lord Phylaster.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p:
O brave fellows; Mureny my fine dear countrymen,
Mutiny. Now my brave valiant foreman, show your weapons In honour of your Mistresses.

sp.speaker: 2 MES.
sp.p: Arm, arm, arm.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: A thousand devils take these Citizens.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: A thousand blessings on them.

sp.speaker: MES.
sp.l: Arm, O king, the City is in Mutiny.
Led by an old gray Ruffian, who comes on
In rescue of the Lord Phylaster.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Away to the Citadel, I will see them safe,
And then cope with these burgers, let the guard
And all the Gentlemen give strong attendance.

div.stage: Exit King, Manet LEON, CLE. and TRA.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: The City up, this was above our wishes.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Aye, and the marriage too, by all the gods, this noble Lady has deceived us all, a plague upon myself, a thousand plagues, for having such unworthy thoughts of her dear Honour: O, I could beat myself, or do you beat me, and I will beat you, for we had all one thought.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: No, no, it will but lose time.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: You say true, are your swords sharpe: Well my dear
Countrymen what you lacks, if you continue, and fall not
Back, upon the first broken skin, I will see you Chronicled,
And Chronicled, and cut and Chronicled, and all to be praised,
And sung in sonnets, and bathed in brave new ballads,
That all tongues shall troll you in Secula seculorum,
My kind Countrymen.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: What if a toy take um in the heels now, and they run all away, and cry, the devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p:
Then the same devil take the foremost too, and sauce him for his breakfast, if they all prove cowards, my curses flush amongst um, and ill speeding: may they have injurious rain to keep the Gentlemen at home in rasine freeze, may the moth branch their velvets, and their silks only be worn before sore eyes, may their false lights undo um, and discover presses, holes, stains, and oldness in their stuffs, and make them shop-rid, may they keep whores, and horses, and break, and live mued up with necks of beef and turnips; May they have many children, and none
like the father, and know no language but that gibberish they prattle to their parcels, unless it be the goatish latin they write in their bonds, and may they write that false, and lose their debts.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Now the vengeance of all the gods confound them,
How they swarm together, what a hum they raise.
Devils choake your wide throats, if a man had need
To use your valours, we must pay a brokage for it,
And then bring on, and you will fight like sheep:
It is Phylaster, none but Phylaster must allay this heat,
They will not hear me speak, but fling dirt at me,
And call me tyrant. O run dear friend, and bring the Lord
Phylaster, speak him well, call him Prince,
Do him all the courtesies you can, commend me to him,
O! my wits, my wits.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: O my brave Citizens, as I live I will not buy a pin
Out of your walls for this: nay, you shall cozen me,
And I will thank you, and send you brawn and bacon,
Every long vocation; and foul shall come up fat
And in brave liking.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: What they will do with that poor Prince, the gods know, I fear.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Why, they will flea him, and make Church buckets on his skin, to quench rebellion, then clap a rivet in his sconce, and hang him up for a sign.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: O worthy Sir, forgive me: Do not make your miseries
And my faults meet together, to bring a greater danger,
Be yourself still sound amongst diseases, I have wronged you,
And though I find it last, and beaten to it,
Let me your goodness know, calm the people, and be
What you were born to, take your love, and with her my repentance,
All my wishes, and all my prayers, by the gods,
My heart speaks all this, and if the least fall from me,
Not performed, may I be struck with thunder.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Mighty Sir, I will not do your greatness so much wrong,
As not to make your word truth, free the Princess and the boy,
And let me stand the shock of this mad sea-breach,
Which I will either turn, or perish with it.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Let your own word free her.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Then thus I take my leave, kissing your hand,
And hanging on your noble word, be Kingly,
And be not moved Sir, I shall bring you peace,
Or never bring myself back.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Now all the gods go with thee.

div.stage: Enter an olde Captaine, with a crew of Citizens, leading PHARAMONT prisoner.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: Come my brave Mermedons, fall on, let your caps swarm, and your nimble tongues forget your gibberish, of what you lack, and set your mouths open children, till your palates fall frighted half a fathom past the cure of bay-salt and gross pepper; and then cry Phylaster, brave Phylaster. Let Phylaster be deep in request, my ding-adings, my pair of dear Indentures: King of clubs, than your cut-water-chamlets, and your painting: let not your hasty silks, dearly belovers of Custards and Cheesecakes, or your branch cloth of bodkins, or your tiffanies, your robin-hood scarlet and Iohns, tie your affections in durance to your shops, my dainty tuckers, up with your three piled spirits, that right valorous, and let your acute colours make the King to feele the measure of your mightiness; Phylaster, cry, my rose nobles, cry.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Phylaster, Phylaster.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.l: How do you like this, my Lord prisoner?
These are mad boys I can tell you,
These be things that will not strike top-sail to a Foist,
And let a Man of war, an Argosy,
Stoop to carry coals.

sp.speaker: PHAR.
sp.p: Why, you damned slaves, do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p:
Yes, my pretty Prince of puppets, we do know, and give you gentle warning, you talk no more such bugs words, lest that sodden
Crown should be scratched with a musket; dear Prince pippin, I will have you coddled, let him lose my spirits, and make a ring with your bills my hearts: Now let me see what this brave man dares do: note sir, have at you with this washing blow, here I lie, do you huff sweet Prince? I could hock your grace, and hang you cross legged, like a Hare at a Poulters stall; and do thus.

sp.speaker: PHAR.
sp.p: Gentlemen, honest Gentlemen —

sp.speaker: 1 SOVL.
sp.p: He speaks treason Captain, shall us knock him down?

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: Hold, I say.

sp.speaker: 2 SOVL.
sp.p: Good Captain let me have one mal at his mazard, I feele my stomach strangely provoked to be at his Spanish pot-nowle, shall us kill him?

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Aye, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: Again I say hold.

sp.speaker: 3 SOVL.
sp.p: O how rank he looks, sweet Captain let us geld him, and send his dowsets for a dish to the Bordello.

sp.speaker: 4 SOVL.
sp.p: No, let us rather sell them to some woman Chemist, that extractions, she might draw an excellent provocative oil from useth them, that might be very useful.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: You see, my scurvy Don, how precious you are in esteem amongst us, had you not been better kept at home, I think you had: must you needs come amongst us, to have your saffron hide tawed as we intend it: My Don, Phylaster must suffer death to satisfy your melancholy spleen, he must my Don, he must; but we your Physicians, hold it fit that you bleed for it: Come my robusticks, my brave regiment of rattle makers, let us call a common cornuted counsel, and like grave Senators, bear up our branched crests, in sitting upon the several tortures we shall put him to, and with as little sense as may be, put your wills in execution.

sp.speaker: SOME CRIES.
sp.p: Burn him, burn him.

sp.speaker: OTHERS.
sp.p: Hang him, hang him.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: No, rather let us carbonado his cods-head, and cut him to collops: shall I begin?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Stay your furies my loving Countrymen.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Phylaster is come, Phylaster, Phylaster.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: My porcupines of spite, make room I say, that I may salute my brave Prince: and is Prince Phylaster at liberty?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I am, most loving countrymen.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: Then give me thy Princely goll, which thus I kiss, to whom I crouch and bow; But see my royal spark, this head-strong swarm that follow me humming like a master Be, have I led forth their Hives, and being on wing, and in our heady flight, have seized him shall suffer for thy wrongs.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Aye, aye, let us kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But hear me, Countrymen.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: Hear the Prince, I say, hear Phylaster.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, hear the Prince, hear the Prince.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: My coming is to give you thanks, my dear Countrymen, whose powerful sway hath curbed the prosecuting fury of my foes.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: We will curb um, we will curb um.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: I find you will,
But if my interest in your loves be such,
As the world takes notice of, Let me crave
You would deliver Pharamont to my hand,
And from me accept this
Testimony of my love.
Which is but a pittance of those ample thanks,
Which shall redound with showered courtesies.

sp.speaker: CAP.
sp.p: Take him to thee brave Prince, and we thy bounty thankfully accept, and will drink thy health, thy perpetual health my Prince, whilst memory lasts amongst us, we are thy Mermidons, my Achillis: we are those will follow thee, and in thy service will scour our rusty murins and our bill-bow-blades, most noble Phylaster, we will: Come my routists let us retire till occasion calls us to attend the noble Phylaster.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Phylaster, Phylaster, Phylaster.

sp.speaker: PHAR.
sp.l: Worthy sir, I owe you a life,
For but yourself there is naught could have prevailed.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: It is the least of service that I owe the King,
Who was careful to preserve ye.

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: I ever thought the boy was honest.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Well, it is a brave boy Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: Yet you would not believe this.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: A plague on my forwardness, what a villain was I, to wrong um so; a mischief on my muddy brains, was I mad?

sp.speaker: TRA.
sp.p: A little frantic in your rash attempt, but that was your love to Phylaster, sir.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: A pox on such love, have you any hope my countenance will ere serve me to look on them?

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: O very well Sir.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: Very ill Sir, uds death, I could beat out my brains, or hang myself in revenge.

sp.speaker: CLE.
sp.p: There would be little gotten by it, even keep you as ye are.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: An excellent boy, Gentlemen believe it, hark the King is coming,

div.stage: Enter the King, Princesse, GALLATEA, MEGRA, BELLARIO, a Gentlewoman, and other attendants.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No news of his return,
Will not this rabble multitude be appeased?
I fear their outrage, lest it should extend
With dangering of Pharamonts life.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: See Sir, Phylaster is returned.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Royal Sir,
Receive into your bosom your desired peace,
Those discontented mutineers be appeased,
And this foreign Prince in safety.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: How happy am I in thee Phylaster?
sp.l: Whose excellent vertues begets a world of love,
I am indebted to thee for a Kingdom.
I here surrender up all Sovereignty,
Reign peacefully with thy espoused Bride,
Assume my Son to take what is thy due.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: How Sir, yer son, what am I then, your Daughter you gave to me.

sp.speaker: KIN.
sp.l: But heaven hath made assignments unto him,
And brought your contract to anullity:
Sir, your entertainment hath been most fair,
Had not your hell-bred lust dried up the spring,
From whence flowed forth those favours that you found:
I am glad to see you safe, let this suffice,
Yourself hath crossed yourself.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: They are married sir.

sp.speaker: PHAR.
sp.p: How married? I hope your highness will not use me so, I came not to be disgraced, and return alone.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: I cannot help it sir.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: To return alone, you need not sir,
Here is one will bear you company,
You know this Ladies proof, if you
Failed not in the say taging.

sp.speaker: ME.
sp.l: I hold your scoffs in vildest base contempt,
Or is there said or done, aught I repent,
But can retort even to your grinning teeths,
Your worst of spites, though Princess lofty steps
May not be tract, yet may they tread a wry,
That boy there —

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: If to me ye speak Lady,
I must tell you, you have lost yourself
In your too much forwardness, and hath forgot
Both modesty and truth, with what impudence
You have thrown most damnable aspersion
On that noble Princess and myself: witness the world;
Behold me sir.

div.stage: Kneeles to LEON, and discouers her haire.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: I should know this face; my daughter.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The same sir.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: How, our sometime Page, Bellario, turned woman?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: Madam, the cause induced me to transform myself,
Proceeded from a respective modest
Affection I bare to my my Lord,
The Prince Phylaster, to do him service,
As far from any lascivious thought,
As that Lady is far from goodness,
And if my true intents may be believed,
And from your Highness Madam, pardon find,
You have the truth.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: I do believe thee, Bellario I shall call thee still.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: The faithfullest servant that ever gave attendance.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Now Lady lust, what say you to the boy now;
Do you hang the head, do ye, shame would steale
Into your face, if ye had grace to entertain it,
Do ye slink away?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Give present order she be banished the Court,
And straightly confined till our further
Pleasure is known.

sp.speaker: PHAR.
sp.p: Here is such an age of transformation, that I do not know how to trust myself, I will get me gone too: Sir, the disparagement you have done, must be called in question. I have power to right myself, and will.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: We fear ye not sir.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Let a strong convoy guard him through the Kingdom,
With him, let us part with all our cares and fear,
And Crown with joy our happy loves success.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Which to make more full, Lady Gallatea,
Let honoured Clerimont acceptance find
In your chaste thoughts.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: It is my suit too.

sp.speaker: PRIN.
sp.p: Such royal spokes-men must not be denied.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Nor shall not, Madam.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: Then thus I join your hands.

sp.speaker: GAL.
sp.p: Our hearts were knit before.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: But it is you Lady, must make all complete,
And gives a full period to content,
Let your loves cordial again revive,
The drooping spirits of noble Trasiline.
What says Lord Leon to it?

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: Marry my Lord I say, I know she once loved him.
At least made show she did,
But since it is my Lord Phylasters desire,
I will make a surrender of all the right
A father has in her; here take her sir,
With all my heart, and heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Then let us in these nuptial feasts to hold,
Heaven hath decreed, and Fate stands uncontrolled.
